Fairly hectic. Friday night I was going to put up our Christmas tree since we didn‚Äôt get to it on December 1st like we usually do, but we both went to bed early. Friday afternoon I stopped at the cell phone place to renew Damien‚Äôs contract and get his new phone, but they didn‚Äôt have stock of the one he wanted. They said they‚Äôd have it for us by 6pm- but with no money I didn‚Äôt want to hang around the mall all evening. I told Damien we‚Äôd go back in the morning. Saturday morning I was awake at 7am- I no longer sleep late because if I‚Äôm not up- Damien gets up to mischief! I did dishes and a load of washing, and then we went to the mall- they had not had the phone delivered! I was miffed at wasting a trip and Damien was disappointed at not getting his new toy. After that we made our way to Damien‚Äôs doctor for our monthly appointment (which is about a 40 minute drive as is) and we got stuck in traffic! I phoned the doc and said we were coming but would be late- and the receptionist said it was cool and not to worry. All in all we arrived 5 minutes late, which I didn‚Äôt think was too bad- but he only called us in an hour later! An hour people! Which meant- of course- that we only left there at nearly noon! My mom had made plans to have the four older grandsons from 11 to 5 for a Christmas party but poor Damien arrived quite late. I dropped him off at my mom so he could party with his cousins, and then I went to sister B to watch ‚ÄúMadagascar‚Äù with her and her hubby. It‚Äôs a very funny movie- the lemur king is hysterical. After that I went home and took my time getting ready for my year end function. Bathed, shaved, washed and blow dried my hair, did my face, got dressed. It was nice and relaxing. Then I grabbed Damien‚Äôs (luckily) already packed (and nearly forgotten) bags and dropped them of at my mom‚Äôs so he could spend the night, collected B‚Äôs boys and took them to her place to pick her up for my year end function. We drove for quite a while to get there- it‚Äôs a long way out and very, very larny (read- expensive, like 13 bux for a beer!). Here‚Äôs what I ate. For my starter I had the ostrich carpaccio topped with pickled ginger and wasabi paste- surprisingly easy on the tongue. For my main course I had a whole fillet of beef grilled and served with a creamy mushroom and truffle sauce, I could cut my beef with a butter knife! My dessert was panna cotta served with granadilla and berry coulis -divine. Sister B chose for a starter, vine ripened tomato, buffalo mozzarella and crisp potato salad with a basil pesto and balsamic dressing- she said she couldn‚Äôt find any potato salad though. For her main course, she had a fillet of kingklip wrapped in streaky bacon topped with a tiger prawn on a warm nicoise salad with a champagne soy sauce- I managed to taste the prawn by stealing a miniscule tit bit off her plate- butter couldn‚Äôt be smoother. Sister B‚Äôs dessert was amarula tiramisu with berry sorbet- which she assured me was better than my panna cotta. Our bosses very generously paid our bar tab for the first part of the evening and B got herself a bottle of wine which lasted her plenty long enough, in fact I don‚Äôt think she finished it. Unfortunately for B and I, one of our company‚Äôs little traditions is tequila- one shot- at meetings and events. B and I used to practically live on the stuff but I think we‚Äôre getting old! Am I allowed to say that B? We were home by about midnight. Oh, one of my colleagues came to me while we were all standing outside chatting and informed me that they had decided to call me ‚ÄúCrystal‚Äù from now on‚Ä¶ nope- no idea! Sunday morning I slept late. Yup, I missed church again. Since there‚Äôs no Sunday school in the school holidays mom had already told me the previous afternoon that she wasn‚Äôt going and I didn‚Äôt set my alarm for it. Either that or I slept through it! When I eventually awoke I got up and did another load of washing and then my mom invited me to join her and Damien for coffee in the little mall across the street. That woke me up. Then Damien and I went home, put away the clean washing, hung up the newest load as it came out of the machine, and then went to the mall to fetch his new cell phone (they had finally had it delivered)! Damien was very excited. Then on the way home we got ‚ÄúCharlie And The Chocolate Factory‚Äù on DVD, watched it on my laptop, and then went to go and see my brother‚Äôs new place. They were still unpacking boxes so we made ourselves useful for a bit. It‚Äôs a really nice place- a two bedroom cottage with a laundry, massive living area, nice open plan kitchen and covered patio on a property inside a gated suburb and right around the corner from sister B! Afterwards I stopped at my folks for coffee quickly and then came home. Damien‚Äôs new phone had been charging for a while and he got to playing with that until bedtime. We still haven‚Äôt put up our Christmas tree and I haven‚Äôt started packing for Damien‚Äôs bus trip yet!!
We need rescue organisations like Wetnose, Barking Mad, Kitty & Puppy Haven and Labrador & Golden Retriever Rescue because people continue to buy animals from breeders!
I know I‚Äôm going to be treading on more than a few toes here, but I really feel strongly about this, today in particular.
Last week I found a dog on the side of the road, and I took him to my vet to stay over for a few days while we tried to make a plan for him. I feel like this makes me more than a little responsible for him.
Tomorrow it will be a week, and my vet can no longer keep him. No one has been looking for him, no one who has been to the vet in the last week is willing to take him on ‚Äì even as a foster ‚Äì and I can‚Äôt afford to bring him home with me.
He‚Äôs now going to the Animal Anti Cruelty League in JHB ‚Äì THANK GOODNESS ‚Äì who will be fetching him from my vet tomorrow morning. I am beyond thrilled that he won‚Äôt be going to the SPCA, but of all the no-kill rescue organisations in Gauteng, the AACL is the only one with space! I called all of them!
Someone cared about this dog. Even if it was just a little bit. He had a collar, and he had been tied up somewhere. He wasn‚Äôt underfed even though he was filthy dirty and he has a few scars. He looks like a small Lab but he has a thick neck like a Staffie. He‚Äôs a really sweet, placid boy and the staff at the vet have become quite fond of him. I had no trouble leashing him and leading him to the car.
It makes me sad that he no longer has a home, and I do hope he will be adopted while at the AACL, but what are the chances? He‚Äôs not a cute little puppy and he‚Äôs not a recognised breed.
And before you bring it to my attention ‚Äì I‚Äôm not referring here to dogs that are bred for a specific purpose, like SAGA‚Äôs Labs and Goldens.
Whilst breeders may sell their puppies ‚Äúto approved homes only‚Äù thats the extent of their responsibility, whilst SAGA monitors the health and welfare of every dog they breed for as long as they are alive.
And with that I add another rescue organisation to my donation list (Wetnose and Lab Rescue are the other two).
Rather donate those thousands to a worthy organisation and adopt a dog already in dire need of a home and love and attention.
For a year or so you have a 5:30am wake-up call; digging; chewing; that divine puppy smell; puppy cuddles; tail wagging; 2am toilet runs- even in the rain; and a bundle of lovable fluff that is deceptively smart.
Many years ago, there was a woman with a guide dog living in the block of flats my son and I lived in. Chatting to her briefly one day when she was out with her dog, she mentioned how the pups are raised by volunteer families, and it piqued my interest- but I was working full time and puppy raising wasn‚Äôt an option.
When I started working from home in 2010, I asked my husband if he would be open to raising a puppy for SAGA, and he said yes.
The following year we applied to SAGA, and a couple of months later they sent a Puppy Development Supervisor to visit us at home and meet us and our dogs and check out the house.
Once we were approved we went onto the waiting list for our puppy, and on December 22nd 2011 I went to fetch Volt, our first guide dog puppy.
I signed our contract at SAGA‚Äôs Puppy Block- after we battled for weeks to come up with a name that started with a U or a V (the letter allocated to his litter)- and after an instructional briefing I left with an adorable puppy, an ID tag, two bags of food, and a 67 page manual.
If you have any idea how cool it is to have an obedient dog, you‚Äôll know how much work goes into training your dog to ‚Äòsit‚Äô or ‚Äòshake‚Äô. Now triple that workload and add to it that you will be supervised to make sure your dog is trained properly, with positive reinforcement! And puppies are a handful, no matter the breed.
When your puppy is awake, it is learning. Not only is there a set of verbal commands (sit, stay, down, off, leave it, come, wait, forward and stand), there‚Äôs all kinds of behavioural conditioning they need to learn as well, and this doesn‚Äôt always have a command.
As a guide-dog-in-training, your puppy is not allowed to chase balls, bark or whine. He has to wait till he‚Äôs told he may eat. He has to be comfortable travelling in a car and must be able to go ‚Äòpotty‚Äô on command. He has to be comfortable in any setting ‚Äì from shopping malls to nursery schools. He has to learn to walk calmly and quietly on a lead, on your left hand side. He has to be taught to WALK (not run) up and down all kinds of staircases. He has to learn not to jump up on people, he may not beg, and he must be taught that noises like thunder and fireworks are nothing to fear. They are with you all the time, they go everywhere with you as much as possible.
And the SAGA PDSs are always on hand to ensure the pups are progressing and you have help if you need it.
You have to remember that you are unofficially representing SAGA when you are out with your puppy. You have to get permission for your puppy to accompany you to places that dogs may not be allowed. Security guards can be a nightmare, and while some people will call out to your puppy when you‚Äôre out together, others scream and jump out of your way as if your puppy is foaming at the mouth!
And people will ask you questions. The same questions over and over again. The most common one being ‚Äú‚Ä¶isn‚Äôt it hard to give them up?‚Äù
Hopefully you‚Äôve done all you were supposed to do and your puppy can start its training as a guide dog with the proper basics already learned.
Your dog‚Äôs trainer will keep you up to date with your dog‚Äôs progress during its guide dog training, but except to meet your puppy‚Äôs new owner when they are ready to graduate and start working together, there is a likelihood you won‚Äôt see your puppy again.
Its a year or so of very mixed feelings‚Ä¶ you want your puppy to do well and take on its life‚Äôs purpose with confidence- but at the same time you love your puppy and you devote a lot of time and attention to it, and you miss your puppy terribly when its gone.
Witnessing your ‚Äúbaby‚Äù, fully trained and walking in his harness with his new owner is a moment filled with so much pride and excitement you are almost fit to burst.
You have to hide behind trees and cars on the other side of the street so that your puppy- and he is still a puppy at that stage- doesn‚Äôt see you and get distracted from his new job!
Our second guide dog puppy, Lennox, is almost 11 months old so our time with him is almost up. Our first guide dog puppy, Volt, is working as a guide dog in the Cape, and the two weekend ‚Äúboarders‚Äù we worked with have also qualified ‚Äì Kenzo as a guide dog in the Cape and Rhody as a service dog in KZN.
We are immensely proud of our puppies, and we plan to raise guide dog puppies for many years to come.
If you think back on your school career- and your children‚Äôs school career, I‚Äôm sure your memories include countless concerts and speech festivals! Probably starting in nursery school!
I remember rehearsals during and after school, late nights performing, costumes made and/or rented, tickets sold, seats booked, sitting through seemingly endless song and dance routines to see your child on stage for maybe 5 minutes‚Ä¶ or in my case ‚Äì watching the teachers trying to catch my child as he ran behind the curtains at the back of the stage!
My precious knucklehead is not a performer. He didn‚Äôt like being on stage, he didn‚Äôt like performing, unfortunately for him he usually didn‚Äôt have a choice. When I was at school I loved the concerts and the speech festivals, I wish I‚Äôd been more confident and shown more of what I was able to do!
I was invited to attend the Tsogo Sun SunCares Arts Academy Showcase for seven Diepsloot primary and secondary schools.
These children spent a year auditioning, training, work shopping and rehearsing to perform on this stage, their first ever concert!
Their unbridled enthusiasm, their confidence, their eagerness to show their audience what they‚Äôve been practising was absolutely infectious!
Dressed to the nines in fabulous, brightly coloured costumes and wigs they‚Äôd had their make up done and they took to the stage like old pros!
I was grinning and laughing and clapping throughout the show, and the one solo by Ndovhedzo Ndouvhada from Diepsloot West Secondary School gave me a lump in my throat and such goosebumps. Wow.
My favourite performance was definitely the ‚ÄúSuperheroes‚Äù from Paradise Bend Primary School! They were so adorable I wanted to put them in my handbag and take them home with me!
The stage is all set for the Tsogo Sun SunCares Performing Arts Academy‚Äôs year-end concerts which will joyfully showcase what 480 youngsters from 12 underprivileged schools in Gauteng have learned through the integrated programme in the course of the year.
Vusi Dlamini, Group HR Director of Tsogo Sun explains, ‚ÄúThe Academy aims to make a real difference in children‚Äôs lives by developing their artistic talent, providing life skills development, and supporting the educational framework by creating extra-curricular activities, as well as potentially providing tertiary opportunities to learners within the programme.
‚ÄúIt was piloted in one school in 2012 and then launched in 2013 as a carefully designed full-year curriculum using the arts as a catalyst to provide opportunities for change in the lives of young people in communities around Johannesburg.‚Äù The SunCares Arts Academy provides a foundation in the basics of drama, dance, vocal training and voice projection, together with a structured lifeskills course that covers a broad spectrum of topics to empower the youngsters to make sound choices throughout their lives.
The Academy is running in seven schools in Diepsloot near Montecasino and five schools in Mayfair near Gold Reef City, with 480 learners in total ‚Äì 40 from each school. The learners go through a rigorous selection process to ensure that they have the potential and the dedication to do well in this Arts programme. Grade 4 to 7 learners are selected for the primary school programme and Grade 8 to 10 for the high school programme. Nine primary schools and three high schools are enrolled in the programme this year.
By the time the end of year concerts come around, the youngsters are bursting with excitement and anticipation ‚Äì and extremely keen to show off their newfound skills to their communities as well as to a wider audience. ‚ÄúThe concerts focus on the performing arts that have been learned through the year and incorporate items that display the different school groups‚Äô dancing and performing skills as well as individuals who have shown particular talent in a specific area,‚Äù says Shanda Paine, Tsogo Sun‚Äôs Group CSI Manager. ‚ÄúThe concerts are inspiring and are quite remarkable evidence of what can be achieved with a lot of enthusiasm, a desire to work hard and apply learnings, well-trained facilitators, and a fine-tuned curriculum.‚Äù
Renowned South African singer PJ Powers is the patron of the Tsogo Sun SunCares Arts Academy and is deriving immense pleasure from time spent with the children, coaching and encouraging ‚Äì and instilling a sense of confidence in their ability to be the best they can be.
Tsogo Sun commissioned Minimax Performing Arts, which has been providing young South Africans with a platform to express themselves through the performing arts for more than 12 years, to develop and run the programme in the schools with four co-ordinating staff members and 12 facilitators who are given on-going weekly training.
As with all Tsogo Sun‚Äôs SunCares programmes, the Arts Academy is founded on strong partnerships with relevant bodies that include the Department of Education, with the schools, with leading learning and training institutions, and increasingly with the communities where the children who attend the academy live. The scepticism that was evident among parents of the selected children at the start of the programme has dissipated as the children‚Äôs academic standards have been maintained, their lifeskills have improved, and they have developed exciting new skills in the performing arts.
The first two concerts are held within the communities where the schools are based and are attended by adjudicators from the National Eisteddfod Association (NEA), who then select the top performers and the best schools to go through to the finals. These will be held at the Lyric Theatre at Gold Reef City on 23 October and will culminate in an awards ceremony for the winners in several categories, including the top high school, the top primary school, the best three individual performers, the most enthusiastic educator and the best performing facilitator.
‚ÄúThis successful initiative has given us the means to provide gifted youngsters from Diepsloot and Mayfair with the knowledge, confidence and lifeskills needed to reach their potential through the performing arts and it is a privilege and a pleasure to be able to give them the opportunity to develop skills and then showcase them on stage in front of an appreciative audience,‚Äù concludes Dlamini. ‚ÄúTsogo Sun is committed to this investment in these young lives and looks forward to many future concerts and to seeing these young lives blossom into accomplished people as they move on in their lives.‚Äù
~~as per my Ladybloggers pledge, I must state here that I was not paid to write this blog post and that all opinions contained herein are mine and mine alone, apart from the official press release of course~~
Yesterday I got to watch something truly remarkable. I got to watch a session where SA Guide-dogs Instructors Hayley and Permit trained their dogs for traffic work.
What this kind of training entails is two instructors, each with one dog at a time, and another instructor in a SAGA vehicle, yesterday it was Guide Dog Services Manager
They do practice this on their training walks with what is referred to as ‚Äúnatural traffic‚Äù, cars that happen to come along during their training, but traffic work is a step up from that.
They head for a quiet suburb, and then using driveways and intersections down the length of about four blocks ‚Äì determined at the start of the session ‚Äì the instructors will walk with their dogs and the instructor in the car will turn into driveways, cross-streets, and approach stop streets in front of the approaching instructor with the dog. Its done at different speeds, sometimes with sudden stops or with the driver of the vehicle backing away and approaching again.
This gives the instructor with the dog the opportunity ‚Äì under controlled circumstances ‚Äì to correctly instruct the guide-dog-in-training on how to react and what to do.
The instructors have two viewpoints to each interaction and should the dog be over-eager, or react with fear, they can correct the behaviour appropriately and gently, and end the interaction on a positive note.
This is essential to prevent the dog from associating approaching traffic with a negative experience.
It also gives the instructors, as a team, the opportunity to observe the dog‚Äôs reactions to cars and crossing streets as part of their eventual decision on who to partner the dog with.
Its phenomenal to see how well the instructors know the dogs, and how patient they are. Not only must they give the same instructions to each of their dogs, they must tailor how they praise and correct behaviour according to the situation AND the individual dog. This is certainly not a cookie-cutter-training process.
There are no assumptions made with regard to a dog‚Äôs progress and personality. An apparently bold dog may be a little nervous in traffic- and vice versa- and each dog is monitored throughout the walk to make sure it has a positive experience and responds properly. And this isn‚Äôt done once for each dog, the training is repeated in different areas and on different days so that the dogs know the ‚Äúrules‚Äù apply no matter where they are, as well as to make sure the dogs are okay in any area.
And get this ‚Äì they have to use different cars and different drivers for these sessions because the dogs are so smart they can actually get accustomed to the drivers and the cars, and they could start thinking that cars can‚Äôt or won‚Äôt actually hurt them since the SAGA staff are so careful during these sessions!
I want to say a big thank you to Guide Dog Mobility Instructor Hayley; her dogs Zaiden, Cayla, Chiva, Elliott and Bramble; Guide Dog Mobility Instructor Permit; his dogs Zama, Shaun, Abby, Ari and Dakota; and Guide Dog Services Manager Gail (who was behind the wheel today), for allowing me to come along and watch you work.
trainer Hayley with Cayla, who is wearing a gentle leader NOT a muzzle (from inside a SAGA car with an instructor behind the wheel)
trainer Permit with Zama, demonstrating not only concentration on traffic, but ignoring other dogs too (from inside a SAGA car with an instructor behind the wheel)!
trainer Hayley with Chiva (not in full harness yet), also wearing a ‚Äúgentle leader‚Äù, which is a training aid NOT a muzzle (from inside a SAGA car with an instructor behind the wheel)
trainer Hayley with Bramble, and ahead of her you can see trainer Permit with Dakota and the SAGA car, driven by another instructor, Gail
trainer Permit with Ari, here you can see an oncoming car thats NOT a SAGA car, this is referred to as ‚Äúnatural traffic training‚Äù
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so easy for a special needs parent to become so wrapped up in advocating for the rights of this tiny community, that their own child fades into the background. I‚Äôm constantly aware of how fine that line is.‚Äù
Stacey is mom to three little boys, the eldest of whom has De Morsier syndrome, and she is an outspoken advocate for Autism (her blog is here).
Her status really hit home for me and it got me thinking about being a parent to a special needs child, and how I parent my knucklehead.
Many times in our lives, as he and I lived with ADHD and I became more and more determined to create awareness and educate people about the disorder, it became all about me.
How I had to take time off work to get to doctors‚Äô appointments and occupational therapy and shrinks and speech therapy and parent teacher meetings and school conferences.
My son needed far more help to get through every day than I did, but sometimes I was crusading so hard and feeling so sorry for myself that he got left behind.
First of all, let me state very clearly ‚Äì so there‚Äôs no doubt ‚Äì if your child is diagnosed with ADHD, you are parenting a child with special needs.
ADHD is often called an invisible disorder, and I must be honest ‚Äì sometimes I am glad for this. If you are a parent to a child with a visible disability or handicap, you are subjected to pitying looks and outright rudeness! Its as if being able to see that someone‚Äôs child is different entitles people to ask questions at point blank range.
Do people REALLY think that the parents of a child with a disability or handicap of any kind have not ALREADY done ‚Äì and are doing ‚Äì as much reading and research as they possibly can?
Look at it this way. If you tell someone your child is asthmatic or diabetic- also fairly invisible disorders- people seldom launch into a diatribe about how its a fake disorder created so drug companies can profit. They‚Äôre still quick to make suggestions about treatments and tell you of their own experiences, but mostly the show concern and empathy.
If you tell someone your child has been diagnosed with ADHD however, they don‚Äôt ask how you‚Äôre doing. There‚Äôs no empathy. They say things like, ‚ÄúOoh is she on Ritalin?‚Äú, ‚ÄúWell I hope you‚Äôre not drugging him!‚Äú, and ‚ÄúOh I was just like him as a child but my parents disciplined me properly.‚Äù
Do you know that children with an ADHD diagnosis have a worse quality of life than children with asthma or diabetes? They don‚Äôt do well at school, they don‚Äôt do well with interpersonal relationships, they‚Äôre always in trouble, and they blame themselves.
For me, raising a special needs child feels like I am always on the defensive. Even now, with a grown up son.
Every single time someone mentions ADHD, I brace myself for the slew of jokes and opinions that inevitably follow, tossed about by people who only ever read YOU and Huisgenoot, or watch Carte Blanche. Even if they‚Äôre not actually talking to me, I have to all but bite my tongue and I am not always successful.
If I‚Äôd worked harder perhaps my son would have finished school. Perhaps he would have gone on to some kind of tertiary education, perhaps he may even have become the Marine Biologist he always wanted to be.

CCT helped the Library of Congress build a national network of master teachers and librarians to create and publish exemplary curricula around its online collections. The Fellows Program combined online, face-to-face, and practicum teaching experiences, enabling educators to develop innovative Web-based humanities curricula and share results with colleagues. This report summarizes responses of Master Teachers to questions from a program application form and a survey administered at the conclusion of every Intel Teach to the Future Master Teacher training in the United States between March 2001 to July 2002. The data reported here demonstrate that Master Teachers' responses to this training have been highly positive throughout the life of the program. Findings reported here include the following:
Master Teachers give high ratings to the curriculum and to the trainers who provided this professional development experience.
Master Teachers report that the program focuses heavily on topics that are the core intended themes of the training.
The data summarized here are referred to in other reports discussing findings from the evaluation of Intel Teach to the Future. Education Development Center's Center for Children and Technology (CCT) has been conducting an independent evaluation of the U.S. implementation of Intel Teach to the Future since March 2000.
Subjects. All teachers who completed the Intel Teach to the Future Master Teacher training were expected to complete this survey. Participant Teachers from this program completed a slightly different version of this survey at the conclusion of their training, and those results are presented in a separate report. Variations between Master Teacher and Participant Teacher responses are noted in this report.
The total number of valid responses to this survey was 1,702. Paired t-tests were used to calculate change in Master Teachers' responses to some questions included both in the application to the program (prior to training) and in the survey administered at the conclusion of the training.
Instruments. The survey is presented in Appendix A. The survey was developed by CCT in consultation with the ICT and Intel staff involved in developing the curriculum. Minor revisions were made to the survey in Spring 2001.
Procedures. This survey was administered via the World Wide Web. Specifically, the survey was mounted within an extranet maintained by Intel for Intel Teach to the Future participants. Teachers were asked to complete the survey at the conclusion of their training. The data reported here were collected between March 2001 and July 2002, with 82% of submissions being made between May and August 2001. The largest number of submissions in a single month (June 2001) was 640.

Kauai Vacation Rentals & Real Estate, Inc is sooooo excited to present our Annual Holiday Feature story! Christmas and New Year‚Äôs Eve are some of our favorite Holidays because it is the time of year we get to see so many guests come back to Enjoy Kauai‚Äôs sunshine and Fun tropical nights ‚Äì and also find time to Chillax with the Family! And of course‚Ä¶ there are Christmas presents, plenty of opportunities to spend time with Santa, and dancing outside on New Year‚Äôs Eve under a sky filled with Fireworks!
Yes! On Kauai, the good times blend into a new year filled with infinite possibilities for greatness and the countdown has already begun! For all our Friends who have always wanted to spent their Holidays on Kauai: here is your chance to re-discover The Garden Island and learn about all the Fun things you can see and do during December and January. For all our returning guests: Whooooo hooooo!!!! We are so excited to see you again AND share great ideas that everyone can Enjoy over the next few weeks.
We call this Feature story ‚ÄúChillaxing in Kauai Wonderland‚Äù because there is plenty of time to chill, relax, sleep, and explore the North and South Shores‚Ä¶ East and West sides of Kauai. This is indeed the season for FUN and it gets even better the moment you land at Lihue Airport. So take a moment now to Enjoy your coffee break‚Ä¶ chill time by the fireplace‚Ä¶ and start getting EXCITED for your Christmas and New Year Holiday Fun on The Garden Island!
The 18th Annual Festival of Lights is now open at Kauai‚Äôs Historic County Building in Lihue, showcasing Aunt Josie‚Äôs Holiday Decoration exhibit. Have you ever seen a Christmas tree made of 7,500 green toothpicks? How about wreaths formed from egg cartons? Table decorations constructed with seed pods? How about a chandelier fashioned from wire coat hangers?!!
According to Wikipedia, Auntie Josie Chansky transformed humble materials into sparkling treasures that she displayed at her homes on Oahu and Kauai. In 1996 the exhibit moved to the Historic County Building and every year since‚Ä¶ Friends, Guests, and Visitors from around the world get to see Auntie Josie‚Äôs homemade crafts and feel the presence of her warm spirit.
The exhibit is now open every Friday, Saturday, and Sunday though December 21st ‚Äì as well as Christmas Eve and December 27th! Admission is FREE and everyone is invited to stop by for a visit. There is plenty of time to browse crafts created by Kauai artisans where many Holiday gifts are waiting for you!
Santa Claus is coming to the Storybook Theatre in Hanapepe Town every Friday night throughout the Holiday season!
On December 19th, and 26th, children can chat with Santa, snack on nutritious treats, and explore historic Hanapepe Town‚Äôs Friday Night Art Night with parents : - )
Hanapepe Town inspired the town featured in the Disney film Lilo and Stitch ‚Äì and Friday Night Art Night has crafts you can buy, restaurants you can explore, and lots of ways to Laugh and Enjoy spending nights outside on Kauai!
On Saturday, December 13th at 7:30 PM, head over to the KCC Performing Arts Center in Lihue and see the 51st Annual ‚ÄúChristmas with the Kauai Chorale‚Äù concert! The weekend show happens again on Sunday, December 14th at 5 PM in the St. Regis Hotel Ballroom!
This year‚Äôs Holiday song list includes Johann Sebastian Bach‚Äôs "Wachet Auf!" ("Sleepers Awake!"); a stirring choral composition called "Hodie" ("This Day") by V. Randall Stroope; lively Christmas pieces in a variety of styles from the classic Bach "Jesu, Joy of Man‚Äôs Desiring"; and songs for Hanukkah, spirituals, solo features, and more!
On Saturday, December 20th, Waimea Town transforms into a kaleidoscope of light, color, and sound when this year‚Äôs parade celebrates another Mele Kalikimaka! (Merry Christmas!!) with The 20th Annual Waimea Lighted Christmas Parade!
Find your spot by 4 PM and stay for the after party at Hofgaard Park! Parking is easier on the Kekaha side of town and everyone who comes early can spend the day in Waimea Enjoying parks, beaches, and hiking trails!
The Waimea Bridge closes at 5:30 PM and re-opens around 8 PM after the parade. The route begins at Waimea Canyon Park, heads down Kaumualii Highway to Alawai Road, turns onto Waimea Road, and continues to the Post-Parade festivities at Hofgaard Park. Dance to live music and entertainment all the way to 11 PM!
Get your beach blankets, chairs, and smiles ready to Enjoy live entertainment, food, and a spectacular display of fireworks at the Poipu Beach Resort Association‚Äôs Annual Fireworks Show! The event is FREE for everyone and the evening is a Wonderful way to Enjoy an exciting show high in the tropical sky!
The show starts around 9 PM and we will keep you posted on additional details we share on our Facebook page, so be sure to LIKE our page and SHARE with your Friends!
There is also a Fun New Year‚Äôs Eve Gala Celebration planned at the St. Regis Princeville Resort! Live music, dancing, and more ‚Äì starting at 10 PM and wrapping up at 1:30 AM. Child care is available and more information is available here!
On December 13th and every second Saturday of the month, the All Saints‚Äô Church hosts a monthly market 9 AM until 2 PM. This is a great opportunity for last-minute Holiday shopping for you and your Family.
The market takes place on the lawn outside the church and includes crafts, jewelry, clothing, produce, plants, food trucks, and a Swap Meet section!
On Sunday, December 14th, come on down to the Princeville Community Center and meet Santa and Mrs. Claus!
The gathering is FREE and takes place from 5 PM to 6 PM. Live Holiday harp music and refreshments make this annual event a FUN time for keiki (kids) of all ages! For more info, click here!

Saturday, December 27th and every last Saturday of the month, Kauai Retreats presents a night of meditation followed by a vegan potluck at Wailua Homesteads.
The evening follows the tradition of Master Sivananda and Swami Vishnu Devananda, whose Satsang meditation provides healing and rejuvenation for the entire body, mind and spirit. The powerful group vibrations produced in meditation, chanting and study transforms the energy level in which you function in your daily life.

Now that you are thinking about your next vacation on Kauai, let us share the secret to having an amazing local Kauai delicacy called Imu turkey. An Imu is an underground oven used throughout Polynesia since ancient times. Many of Kauai‚Äôs luaus use Imu ovens to roast the pig for your gourmet feast. However‚Ä¶ when you cook your Thanksgiving turkey in an Imu, the result is a mouthwatering delicacy!
Imagine how delighted your Family will be when you serve them succulent, juicy-moist turkey that falls from the bone and onto your Thanksgiving dinner plate. Sounds delish, yeah? Your Imu turkey dinner can be flavored with pineapple and basted with Soy sauce.
This year, the Kauai Robotics Alliance is hosting the 4th Annual Kauai Imu Turkey cookout! This fundraiser lets you drop off your turkey between 1 PM and 2 PM on Wednesday, November 26th ‚Äì and pick it up Thursday, November 27th, cooked and ready for your own Imu dinner at your Kauai Vacation Rentals & Real Estate, Inc accommodation! Your Family will thank you and so will your tummy!
To make your reservation, click this link and email Kauaibots ‚Äì or give them a call at (808) 635-7377. What a wonderful way to Enjoy your Thanksgiving feast with minimal effort and MAXIMUM JOY!

Kauai‚Äôs North Shore is famous for breathtaking ocean views, shops, beaches and surfing. The North Shore is also where you and your Family can spend hours on the golf course and be amazed by the natural beauty all around you. Let us introduce you to the Prince Golf Course in Princeville.
This stunning golf course combines the backdrop of the Pacific Ocean with beautiful views of Kauai‚Äôs Mountains to the north. The multi-million dollar renovation was overseen by renowned architect Robert Trent Jones, Jr., who originally designed this course. The results put this course high on the list of ‚Äúmust-play‚Äù locations for avid golfers.
Named after Prince Albert, son of Hawaii‚Äôs King Kamehameha IV and Queen Emma, the Prince Golf Course will help you feel like royalty. The award-winning par-72 course is ranked by Golf Digest as the ‚Äú#1 Golf Course in Hawaii‚Äù and ‚Äúone of America‚Äôs Top 100 Greatest Courses.‚Äù Golf Week also rates the course among ‚ÄúAmerica‚Äôs ‚ÄúBest 100 Resort Courses‚Äù and Golf Magazine includes it in the ‚ÄúTop 100 Courses.‚Äù
From the first tee to the 18th green, you will know why this course is a golfer‚Äôs dream! Lucky for all of us, there are more great golf courses to explore on the North Shore!
The Makai Golf Club (above) offers one of Hawaii‚Äôs premier championship layouts with 27 holes, located at the Princeville Resort. Also designed by Robert Trent Jones, Jr., the Makai opened in 1971 and is consistently ranked as one of Hawaii‚Äôs top golf experiences.
The Makai Golf Club was reopened in early 2010 after a wonderful renovation and now consists of two uniquely individual courses. The 18-hole Makai Course incorporates original Lake and Ocean nines, and plays to a par 72 with four sets of tees extending the course to more than 7,200 yards. The signature 7th hole on this course plays to 213 yards from the back tees. It opens with a difficult tee shot over scenic cliffs onto a green surrounded by sandy bunkers and a backdrop of the mountains and Pacific Ocean.
For casual golfers, the 9-hole Woods Course offers a leisurely game in a more relaxed layout. The course winds through the native woodlands of Kauai‚Äôs North Shore and provides a Fun, scenic afternoon for everyone.
In the mood to tighten up your game? The updated facility features 2 large new practice tees, a practice fairway bunker, a short game practice center, and seven target greens. Combined with its knowledgeable staff, the Makai Golf Club is a premier destination for all golfers!
Poipu Bay Golf Course was home to the PGA Championship from 1994-2006, and is the only course that provides a stunning view of ‚ÄúMahaulepu,‚Äù an undeveloped part of Kauai‚Äôs coastline where you get a distant view of rock formations over 5 million years old. This amazing view helps fill your golf day with Fun and Amazement.
Designed by Robert Trent Jones, Jr. (can you tell he knows his golf courses?) ‚Äì Poipu Bay Golf Course features 210 oceanfront acres that meander and weave along Kauai‚Äôs coastline. Within this course sits 85 bunkers, 5 ‚Äòwater hazards,‚Äô and winds that change daily ‚Äì making each round a unique and individual experience! Combine this with 30 acres of tropical plants, flowers, and coastal views of humpback whales spouting in the distance (during winter months) and we have a golf course that is exceptionally Kauai! Also, the golf carts feature satellite navigation so you never will get lost looking for your ball!
Poipu Bay Golf Course also has historical and cultural significance. It is designed around ancient places of worship (heiau) and handmade stone walls estimated to be over 500 years old. Golfers may find peace of mind while playing their ball around these special areas.
Situated in Poipu, it is another amazing course designed by the one and only Robert Trent Jones, Jr. It too features remnants of an authentic Hawaiian village built into this unique course that also showcases beautiful scenery in a challenging golf environment.
One cool thing about The Kiahuna Golf Club‚Äôs website is that it offers tips from their golf pros on how to play each of their holes. Before your trip, visit the site and view the pictures and watch the videos so you‚Äôll have a head start on conquering this challenging course.
After your game, grab your Friends and head to Joe‚Äôs on the Green where you can relax and have a nice tropical beverage and share stories about your day on the links.
The Kauai Lagoons Golf Club in Lihue offers 27 holes designed by golf legend Jack Nicklaus. ‚ÄúThe Kiele Course‚Äù is an 18-hole course that weaves through mango trees and takes golfers through Kauai‚Äôs ‚ÄúAmen Corner.‚Äù (That‚Äôs an area that once you make it past, folks often say 'amen' and keep going!)
The outward nine boasts the longest continuous stretch of ocean holes on Hawaii. WOW! Look at the photo above. Can you smell the ocean air already? We can!
The Waikane Nine, also at Kauai Lagoons Golf Club, is a more ‚Äòforgiving‚Äô course that is especially suited for juniors and families. At 12 noon you can combine the Waikane Nine with the Kiele Mauka Nine for an affordable 18-hole round of golf. This is GREAT for Kauai travelers who want to golf and maintain a set budget. Either way, the views and experience of playing this unique course will stay with you long after your visit. : - )
Another great course on the East Side is the Puakea Golf Course with its majestic views of Mount Haupu and the Pacific!
Designed by one of Hawaii‚Äôs most renowned architects, Robin Nelson, this course utilizes deep ravines and mountain water-fed streams to challenge players and surround them in Kauai‚Äôs natural beauty splendor! Each round is different at Puakea as the position of the sun, direction of the wind, and course characteristics help you and your Friends have the best day ever. : )
Before you leave for Kauai, check your airline‚Äôs policy on golf clubs. Some airlines place limits on checked items and a hard golf case is recommended to protect your clubs. For more useful advice for flying with clubs, visit GolfLink here. Another idea is shipping your clubs to Kauai.
If you prefer to leave your clubs at home, the golf pro shop at Makai Golf Club in Princeville has knowledgeable staff who can assist you in finding a perfect set of clubs for your Golf adventure!
WOW! There is sooooo much for golfers to experience on Kauai. And the great news? There is still plenty more to do! While you are on the golf course and after your game, join the Family for splashing in the water, going on a hike, relaxing at the spa, and after the day is done‚Ä¶ Enjoy a fun night on the town!

Ahhhhh. Just thinking about my vacation makes me want to head back to the airport tomorrow morning! I spent 6 days on the South Shore in August and every day felt like I won a dream vacation right out of a magazine!
I am a single mom who works around the clock and rarely takes time for vacation. And every day this year I kept seeing these awesome photos posted by Kauai Vacation Rentals & Real Estate, Inc and sometimes I would just sit in front of my computer screen rubbing suntan lotion on my arms while drinking iced tea with a little umbrella poking out above the rim of my glass. Then I would close my eyes and imagine myself stand up paddle boarding while Poipu Beach glistens in the background.
Then it dawned on me. I CAN BE THAT PERSON in the photo! I WANT to go to the Hukilua! I AM the woman sitting on the boat gliding through paradise watching my kid‚Äôs hair blowing in the wind. So without hesitation I called my mom and said ‚Äúhow would you like to go to Kauai with me and my daughter?!?!‚Äù
She howled with excitement and set the phone down suddenly and, before I knew it, she was walking through my front door! (She lives close by!) She was already wearing her sun hat talking about the movie ‚ÄúSouth Pacific‚Äù and with that burst of excitement I became even more excited! The days flew by as we started planning all our adventures, and thanks to all the Fun things Kauai Vacation Rentals & Real Estate, Inc shares on Facebook, we knew a fantastic vacation was about to unfold!
And oh how fun it was! When my Friends at Kauai Vacation Rentals & Real Estate, Inc asked me to share my ‚ÄúTop 5 Highlights‚Äù from my Spectacular Summer Vacation on Kauai, I did not hesitate. Believe me, if you are looking for a great vacation destination to please a child under 10, a grandma/mom over 70, and a business woman over‚Ä¶ eh‚Ä¶ well let‚Äôs just say ‚Äúforever 30‚Äù‚Ä¶ Kauai should be at the top of everyone‚Äôs list!
Before getting to Kauai, I researched lots of Fun things to do and I made a list. Then when I got to Kauai, I just decided to ‚Äúlet each day happen.‚Äù That means on some days I got to rise with the sun and meditate and do yoga on the beach. Other days, my daughter woke me up with her own list of things she wanted to do.
Every day we had options, like Kauai Backcountry Tubing at the former Lihue Plantation, a day at sea with Captain Andy‚Äôs Na Pali Coast Tour, and spending time in the glorious sun at Poipu Beach. Yes, the ‚Äúorganizing‚Äù side of my brain wanted to plan every moment and every meal in advance ‚Äì and somehow, letting it all go and ‚Äúflowing‚Äù day-to-day made this Kauai vacation extra special. I know my family and I will remember it forever!
Seriously, I had never heard that word before nor did I know what it was until we got there. What a blast!
SNUBA¬Æ is a cross between ‚Äúsnorkeling‚Äù and shallow water ‚Äúscuba‚Äù ‚Äì without the need to get certified or having to be an expert underwater diver! For me, that means grandma could have an underwater swim with my daughter and me while being expertly watched by a SNUBA¬Æ instructor/guide.
The website says it is like swimming in a giant aquarium surrounded by tropical fish. It was more like exploring ‚Äúunder the sea‚Äù where we would expect to find Ariel (the Little Mermaid) and her underwater friends Flounder and Sebastian. It was so much Fun and the activity includes expert instruction with the convenience of always being 20 feet away from the ‚Äúsecurity‚Äù raft floating on the surface.
Captain Andy knows how to deliver a great time! Trip Advisor ranks it the #1 in tourist attractions on Kauai and getting to see parts of the island that are inaccessible by car made us feel like we were on an adventure, custom-made for us!
The activity‚Äôs official website says ‚ÄúThis fifteen-mile stretch of rugged coastline on the northwest shore of Kauai literally means "the Cliffs." Much of Na Pali Coast is inaccessible due to its characteristic sheer cliffs that drop straight down, thousands of feet into the ocean. Sailing, rafting and hiking are the best ways to experience Na Pali's myriad of natural wonders.‚Äù
I am so glad we took this tour! We saw dolphins, Flying fish, and everywhere we looked there were amazing views!
On this trip we took the Sunset Cruise, which is great because we got to see Kauai lit up by the twilight sun. There is also a daytime cruise that can be paired with snorkeling, which is exactly what we will be doing for sure on our next trip!
I was determined to learn how to surf on this trip and my daughter was like, ‚Äúyou‚Äôre doing it ‚Äì I am doing it!‚Äù So we were excited to book with Kauai Surf School.
The waves on the South Shore were perfect and the instructors are very friendly! This school is great for people of all ages and although my mom didn‚Äôt hang ten on the surf board, she had a great time taking lots of pictures!
After our day of surfing, we took time to ‚Äúrelax‚Äù and kick back on Poipu Beach. I did the research and the tips Kauai Vacation Rentals & Real Estate, Inc share on Twitter are true! It is a GREAT beach for families! Body surfing, snorkeling, and the shallow protected area is ideal for kids. We had turtle sightings every day and the Nukumoi Surf Shop across the street is convenient for water shoes or anything else you may need for a day at the beach!
My vote: The instructors at Kauai Surf School are awesome and Poipu Beach is also a perfect spot for sunrise yoga and morning runs!
I love that we rented a car on Kauai. It really gave us the ability to do whatever we wanted and Enjoy our vacation ‚Äúfamily time.‚Äù Another highlight is the 2-mile hike we took at Shipwrecks Beach. It is part of the Mahaulepu Heritage Beach Trail.
According to the website: it is the last stretch of undeveloped coastline on the South Shore. The Mahaulepu Heritage Beach Trail is a great coastal hike that takes you from the southeast corner of Shipwrecks Beach / Keoiloa Bay along sand-dune cliffs, Kiawe trees, limestone formations and rocky inlets where you can see sea turtles and Hawaiian Monk Seals.
My photo on the right shows the terrain and I want to say‚Ä¶ when you are standing here, you feel a majestic sense of peace and tranquility that makes you feel like you are really on vacation in a place far from the routines back home.
Another great spot we visited is Spouting Horn. Also on the South Shore, waves push water through a rock formation and water then sprays up into the air, like a Hawaiian Old Faithful. Nearby shops are totally cute and a great place to buy souvenirs and jewelry, which I am wearing now! : - )
Then there is Wailua Falls. The beautiful water flowing overhead made me feel like I was in the opening shot of ‚ÄúFantasy Island!‚Äù The plane, the plane! The double waterfall is magical!
I have been home for about 2 weeks now and every morning when I wake up, I think about the smile on my face, my daughter‚Äôs face, and my mom‚Äôs face. Kauai is a wonderful vacation destination with hiking and activities we all Enjoyed. In the back of my mind, I pictured Kauai as a perfect place to chill, kick back on the ocean, and do nothing. Well‚Ä¶. There was certainly ‚Äúchill‚Äù time, and there are also plenty of FUN activities for everyone ‚Äì and being outdoors spending quality time with my family was a reward and a spectacular treat.
We did ‚Äúchill‚Äù one day, and for the most part I started my day at 6 AM with yoga, then did a big activity at 9 AM or 1 PM or 3 PM (that's when the tour-type things leave). I probably spent at least 2 hours a day in the pool or at the beach. And yes, we definitely found time for shopping!
We love Poipu Shopping Village and The Shops at Kukui'ula Village, where we bought clothes, souvenirs, and ate some fabulous meals. I would say I was pretty active on this 6-day holiday and I still found time to read, take a nap, and keep my 10-year old moving and having Fun.
I now know where I want to vacation every chance I can! My daughter wants to move there and says it was the best trip ever. She basically lived in the water and even though our schedule was busy, it didn‚Äôt feel over programmed. In fact, it was exquisitely perfect. : -)
Now, the memories of making leis, taking hula lessons, feeding koi, surfing, snuba‚Äôing, shopping, tubing, and hiking have me smiling and counting the days till our next visit.

NEW YORK [Oct. 9, 2017] HGTV and Macerich today announced that a classic holiday tradition returns with HGTV‚Äôs popular Santa HQ experience‚Äîan event that has reinvented the traditional Santa Claus visit at malls across America since 2014. HGTV and Macerich mall properties will host this year‚Äôs merrymaking at 15 sites in Arizona, California, Colorado, Connecticut, Illinois, New Jersey, New York, Oregon and Washington, D.C. Santa HQ will welcome guests seven days a week beginning Thursday, Nov. 2, through Sunday, Dec. 24 (closed Thanksgiving Day).
Santa HQ connects the HGTV brand with millions of targeted consumers in markets across the country, thrilling guests of all ages with a 21st century immersive journey that features state-of-the-art digital technology. In addition to a custom photo opportunity with Santa Claus inside his modernized sleigh, mall guests can take an Elfie selfie to star in their very own holiday video, use Elf-Ray Vision to explore Santa‚Äôs Observatory and find out how they rank on the Naughty or Nice O‚ÄôMeter. Visitors also will enjoy a synchronized holiday light show featuring over 10,000 individual lights orchestrated to the tune of Carol of the Bells.
While visiting Santa HQ, guests can customize their individual experience by using augmented reality to view Santa‚Äôs Workshop and Observatory in a magical way. Visitors are encouraged to download the Elf-Ray Vision app or use a provided tablet to discover the enchanting world of Santa HQ in stunning 2D and 3D digital scenes.
‚ÄúFor the past three years, Santa HQ has been an unforgettable holiday experience for tens of thousands of HGTV fans,‚Äù said Shannon Driver, general manager, U.S. brand marketing, Scripps Networks Interactive. ‚ÄúThe network is thrilled to partner once again with Macerich to offer this interactive event full of wonder and fun that makes the season even more special for families.‚Äù
The unique attraction offers a powerful HGTV brand experience at each of the high-performing, market-dominant Macerich properties that host Santa HQ. ‚ÄúThis holiday season, Macerich properties are set to unwrap great experiences for shoppers, including the incomparable Santa HQ,‚Äù said Petra Maruca, Vice President of Business Development, Macerich. ‚ÄúThis one-of-a-kind interactive attraction, created in partnership with HGTV, has become a well-loved tradition at top Macerich centers across the country. We are delighted to again offer this exciting Santa experience that families can share.‚Äù
Reservations for each location can be made in advance santa-hq.com. HGTV knows the holiday season is a memorable time for the network‚Äôs audience, so fans are encouraged to share their Santa HQ experience on Twitter, Facebook and Instagram using #santahq and #loveHGTV.
Santa HQ was conceived in collaboration with HGTV, Macerich and Pop2Life, a New York-based experiential marketing agency.

In Ontario, there are laws about access to health care services and to Ontario Health Insurance Plan (OHIP) coverage.
In Ontario, the Residential Tenancies Act (RTA) sets out the law related to rent increases, evictions, repairs, and other issues that affect tenants. The RTA applies to most rental housing, although there are some living arrangements and rental situations it does not apply to.

I don‚Äôt even know where to begin when it comes to unemployment and young people without sounding like an old doucher (insert old man voice here: ‚ÄúI remember when I was a youngster and times were tough, we did whatever it took to make a dollar.‚Äù) but I just read a post by Herb Engert that put me over the edge. In it, he addresses the frightening statistics of joblessness among young people today. The entrepreneurs in the 30 and under group he researched suggested five key imperatives for action: expand funding alternatives, increase mentoring and broader support, change the culture to tolerate failure, target and speed up incentives, and reduce red tape and excessive taxation. Though compelling, these suggestions from this particular group make me want to blow my top, and here‚Äôs why.
I‚Äôve been working with Gen Y and Millenials for close to a decade, and I have been stunned by the decline in personal responsibility, drive, and motivation each year has brought to each new population of young people I work with. I‚Äôve witnessed a 23+ year old have a public tantrum because his instructor ‚Äúdidn‚Äôt respect‚Äù him (actually, I‚Äôve lost count of how many students have publicly decried being ‚Äúdisrespected‚Äù by an instructor because the instructor didn‚Äôt let them off the hook). I‚Äôve had to take countless telephone calls from parents of 20somethings and 30somethings complaining that their child isn‚Äôt learning anything and then, when confronted with the fact that their child has a 67% attendance rate, giving excuse after excuse as to why we should allow their (adult) child off the hook (‚ÄúShe‚Äôs having a really bad year,‚Äù ‚ÄúShe just got her 2nd D.U.I. and she‚Äôs really depressed,‚Äù ‚ÄúHe has insomnia and can‚Äôt be at school by 9:00. Can‚Äôt you make an exception?‚Äù) I‚Äôve been saddened by the W.I.F.M. sense of entitlement that is so pervasive among this population, their cutthroat, back-stabbing, reality-TV-esque interactions. The ‚ÄúEven though you may be smarter, stronger, or better than me, I‚Äôm going to make sure you lose, or at least look bad, so that I look better; even though I‚Äôm not going to do anything to be better, smarter, or stronger. I just don‚Äôt want you to win because if you win, we‚Äôre not on the same level.‚Äù I guess I shouldn‚Äôt be shocked. After all, this is the generation where everyone won a trophy, whether they played by the rules or not. Maybe all this nonsense started there.
When I was growing up (again, insert old man voice here), if you played on a team there were winners and there were losers. If you won, you celebrated. If you lost, you licked your wounds for a minute but then you went out and practiced that much harder. No one wanted to suck or be a loser. Fast forward twenty years and at little league and t-ball fields across the nation, kids learned that it didn‚Äôt matter if they won or lost, they would still win a trophy anyway. I‚Äôm pretty sure that‚Äôs when the coaches stopped being allowed to teach kids to win because parents didn‚Äôt like it when their kid cried because they sucked ‚Äì I mean, lost. So, coaches stopped coaching (or, bullying, as some psychotic parents suggested) and started telling the kids that ‚Äúeveryone is a winner,‚Äù which we all know is horse shit and the parents all patted their kids‚Äô heads and nodded their own heads in agreement. Or, maybe this phenomenon occurred when parents, guilty because they both had to work long hours at the office to maintain their American Dream ‚Äì Toll Brothers McMansions, mid-size luxury sedans and SUVs, golf, Abercrombie & Fitch, riding lessons, Uggs, and The Northface for the kids ‚Äì decided to let their kids off the hook for everything. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt feel like cleaning my room,‚Äù ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to go to practice,‚Äù ‚ÄúAmy has the new Uggs. I can‚Äôt believe you won‚Äôt get them for me,‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat do you mean we can‚Äôt go to Great Wolf Lodge for a week? You suck!‚Äù Exhausted and over-worked, parents started picking their battles, discipline, dedication, drive, and ass-kicking competitiveness obvious losers, lifeless on enemy soil. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, sweetheart. We‚Äôll make it work,‚Äù they replied. ‚ÄúI was going to get you those Uggs for Christmas, honey,‚Äù they quickly recovered. ‚ÄúI know your team lost today but you will always be a winner,‚Äù they lied. And their kids, smug with a win, nodded in agreement, their Facebook likes, Twitter and Instagram followers, an obvious confirmation of their awesomeness (right?). The fascinating thing about this? These same parents are (gasp) shocked that their adult kids are a.) still living at home or, b.) moving back home after unsuccessful jaunts in the real world due to their unrealistic expectations of how the real world should operate (‚ÄúWhat do you mean I‚Äôm not getting promoted to vice president of the company after being here for six months?‚Äù ‚ÄúThey treated me like shit. Like who the fuck are they to ask me to make copies for them?‚Äù ‚ÄúI could run that shit a thousand times better than they do.‚Äù).
On the flip side, there are some things I admire about this generation (shocking, right?). I love the fact that they are more open to creating their own careers and that they have no fear when it comes to doing just that. I admire their confidence when it comes to self-promotion. In fact, I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve ever seen so many people tout their awesomeness, whether true or not, and the fact that they can build a business off of the spin they generate about themselves is amazing. My generation had to have proof in their pudding before they spouted off about how excellent they were but, as a result, have built long-term success is their careers and the businesses they developed. For example, alongside my husband, I helped grow our business to several million dollars a year in business from the ground up. We had no choice of funding alternatives ‚Äì we went to a family friend who loaned us money to use as collateral to get more money from the bank. We had no mentors or support ‚Äì the company we franchised with was brand new to the franchising game so, we in essence, grew up along with them. We would NEVER expect culture to change to accept our failure ‚Äì failure wasn‚Äôt an option, period. We had no government incentives ‚Äì we had achievement and success and pride as incentives. And, taxation? It is what it is and we made sure our profit margin fit within our tax structure. So, with that said, the five key initiatives I would suggest to young entrepreneurs are this:
1. Stop whining about what you need and wondering who is going to hand it to you. We don‚Äôt need to expand funding alternatives so that you can start your business. Like most people that have built successful businesses before you, get up off your ass and go make it happen.
2. Stop expecting other people to create what you need. It‚Äôs hilarious to me that with allllllll the thousands of ‚Äúfriends and followers‚Äù you guys all have via social media, you‚Äôre crying that you need us to create business networking groups for you guys to more readily share information. Instead of telling your thousands of friends and followers what you drank last night at happy hour, or what you‚Äôre eating for lunch today, why don‚Äôt you ask them if they can recommend a mentor? Or, if you want to build a support network for your entrepreneurial aspirations, why don‚Äôt you use your social media skills to build one? Or, should we create an association to do that for you, too? I just read something in a John Maxwell book that said something like, ‚ÄúIf you want a glass of milk, you don‚Äôt go out and sit in a field expecting the cow to walk up to you and put its nipples in your hands.‚Äù Sage advice, obviously paraphrased, but sage advice, nonetheless.
3. STOP ACCEPTING FAILURE AS AN OPTION AND STOP EXPECTING US TO ACCEPT YOUR FAILURE AS AN OPTION FOR YOUR FAILURE. It is nauseating to go back and reread the three bullet points: government needs to promote entrepreneurs as crucial job creators (no they don‚Äôt if you do what you say you‚Äôre going to do), society needs to be more tolerant of failure and recognize entrepreneurs as innovators (‚ÄúEven if you lost today, you‚Äôll always be a winner to me, sweetheart.‚Äù Is that what you need? Then you‚Äôre not cut out to be an entrepreneur.), schools and universities must help students make the right career choices (oh, that‚Äôs right, we need to parent you because your parents were so busy telling you how awesome you are and how you‚Äôll be successful at anything as long as you believe you‚Äôre successful, that they forgot to tell you that if you want to be successful you have to work your fucking ass off.)
4. Stop looking to the government to create solutions to your inability to make shit happen. Sure, it would be great if there was a program that could help everyone become an entrepreneur but if you look at programs the government creates to help everyone, there are rarely any self-made success stories. Quite the opposite.
5. Taxation is what it is. If you think the government is going to lower taxes, or make special concessions because you want to start a business and it needs to be easier, then you‚Äôre not cut out to be an entrepreneur. Big businesses that have received special tax loopholes became so successful WITHOUT those loopholes that they can now hire people to go to Washington and create new loopholes for them. Soooooo, in other words, go get super successful and then you, too, can get special tax treatment.
In closing, I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôm going to receive tons of flack for this post (‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know what it‚Äôs like to be young,‚Äù ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre negative,‚Äù ‚ÄúYou suck,‚Äù ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a dream killer,‚Äù ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre already successful. Fuck you,‚Äù ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt understand what these kids are going through,‚Äù ‚ÄúBlah, blah, blah‚Äù) but I‚Äôm reminded of a quote when I think of this, as I, like Herb, do often. It‚Äôs from my husband‚Äôs grandfather who used to say: ‚ÄúShit in one hand and wish in the other. See which one fills up faster.‚Äù Herb was right when he said that this is a generation that can be great, but it has to start with young folks not wishing but taking action; however, shitting in their hand isn‚Äôt necessarily an action I would suggest.
I was saddened to hear of the death of His Eminence Cardinal J√≥zef Glemp, the former Primate of Poland and Archbishop of Warsaw, on Wednesday at the age of 83.
Cardinal Glemp was an eminent figure in the history of the Roman Catholic Church in Poland, having guided the Polish Church through a very difficult period in its history.
As a close associate of Cardinal Stefan Wyszy≈Ñski, and later Blessed John Paul II, he was entrusted with a key responsibility as Archbishop of Gniezno in 1981, which made him Primate of Poland.
As head of the Polish Bishops‚Äô conference, he was to lead his flock through a time of severe Communist repression during the 19 month period of Martial Law. While he was often under pressure to take political positions, he steadfastly remained focused on the spiritual well-being of the faithful, knowing that this was the key to defeating the morally bankrupt Communist regime.
When the Jaruzelski regime finally fell in 1989, His Eminence Cardinal Glemp led the revival of the Polish Church in free Poland, leaving a proud legacy of accomplishments including the construction of the National Temple of Divine Providence in Warsaw. In 2009, His Eminence received a well-deserved Order of the White Eagle for his contributions to the Polish nation from the hands of President Lech Kaczynski, who later died tragically.
Cardinal Glemp belonged to that generation of Polish leaders who had to rebuild a Poland deeply scarred by the experience of two totalitarian empires, the legacy of brutal war, the execution of the Holocaust in their midst, and a public life built on lies. He made his own remarkable contribution to this difficult task of historical recovery, cultural restoration and reconciliation between peoples.
Today I join Canada‚Äôs Polish community and the people of Poland in mourning the passing of this remarkable religious leader, and in praying for the repose of his soul.

The ASVAB is a series of tests developed by the Department of Defense and is used by the U.S. Army to determine whether you have the mental aptitude to enlist. The ASVAB also helps determine which Military Occupational Specialties (MOS) you qualify for. The ASVAB is required to enlist in the U.S. Army and is valid for two years. The ASVAB may be given in a computerized version at a Military Entrance Processing Station (MEPS) or in a paper version at various Military Entrance Test (MET) sites around the country or at high schools and colleges.

Founder & Editor-in-Chief of The 7th Magazine: An entrepreneurial spirit who aspires to inspire. I'm an islander born in Puerto Rico & raised in Sint Maarten. I am grateful that she's learning to be independent in some ways. She can dress and undress herself, go potty by herself, and get basic snacks from the pantry. But along with that new found independence comes this phrase "Grace do it!" I swear if I never heard that again, I'd be perfectly happy; but alas, I'm sure I will hear it within about 2 minutes of her waking up in the morning. I hear it constantly. Try to help her get her shoes on? "Grace do it!" Try to help her sit on the potty? "No mama, go away. Grace do it!"
Her new found independence has led to her desire to change her clothes literally at least 10 times a day. While I'm busy with Connor she will sneak into her room and 5 minutes later will come out in a completely different outfit. Sometime she announces it to me "look mama, new clothes!" Other times she will try to sneak it past me, hoping I won't notice after I have told her time and time again to leave the clothes on that we put on that morning. I guess she thinks that I don't enough laundry to do! Oh and each time she changes, she adds a new hair accessory and shoes. Her closet is constantly a wreck because of her digging through it to find her latest ensemble. She has now taken it upon herself to pick my clothes for me as well. This day she was being nice and giving me a choice between two shirts. When I told her I needed something long sleeved, she said with authority "No mama, this one or this one!"
Recently, she has decided that she is now Connor's caretaker and boss. Overall it's adorable and hilarious, but he's not always thrilled about her "instructions." While I was doing laundry today, I poked my head out to find her checking the back of his diaper. She pulled it back, made a face, and told me that he pooped. I'd never seen her check like that before but she obviously knew what to do! Later, she lined up their two chairs, told him to sit down and instructed him to hold her hands. He wasn't thrilled but did what he was told.
I don't know exactly what he intention was but she was content with this. It lasted for a few seconds before he pulled away screaming. She tried to convince him to do it again, but he wouldn't do it. After a couple minutes of this, I told them to pick up the train pieces that you can see thrown all over the living room. In true 3 year old form, I saw Grace go pick up the bin and say to Connor "pick up trains Onnor (her name for him.) In here, pick up!" She showed him how to put one piece in and proceeded to hold the bin while he picked the pieces up. I didn't let that fly and made her pick up as well, which she was not thrilled about.
She's so full of personality and I'm always amazed to see what she's going to do next. She's actually having a speech evaluation done next week because she's still not talking a ton so I'll update when I know more about that. Having a 3 year old is definitely challenging, I'm not looking forward to her teenage years!!

An elegant and classic French white wine for gifting. Presented in a red cardboard gift box. Pale gold colouring. Limpid and brilliant wine. Developed bouquet of floral notes and ripe fruit (pears) rounded off by spices and a hint of toast. Nice balance in the mouth between roundness and mineral tension. A slight oakiness, along with floral notes, is noticeable in the finish.
A classic French red for the Bordeaux lover! This wine comes presented in a single bottle red cardboard gift box. Deep ruby colour. Nose of spice cake, liquorice and red fruit. The palate is powerful and smooth, with very elegant and blended tannins.
An elegant and classic French white wine for gifting. Presented in a wooden box with sliding lid. Pale gold colouring. Limpid and brilliant wine. Developed bouquet of floral notes and ripe fruit (pears) rounded off by spices and a hint of toast. Nice balance in the mouth between roundness and mineral tension. A slight oakiness, along with floral notes, is noticeable in the finish.
A two bottle gift, in a red cardboard gift box. Both classic styles of wine, this makes a great gift for the French wine lover. The red - Chateau Lyonnat - is deep ruby in colour with a nose of spice cake, liquorice and red fruit. The palate is powerful and smooth, with very elegant and blended tannins. The white - Gerard Tremblay, Chablis - show great minerality, yet isn't aggressive, with trademark green and red apple aromas. The palate is whistle-fresh with lime, apple and more minerals showing. The overall impression is of a perfectly balanced, fleshy and ripe wine. A great duo indeed.

This Champagne comes beautiful packaged with two excellent quality Gosset Champagne flutes and a Gosset champagne closer.

The red is an equally delicious bottle - an organic red Cahors, Chateau de Chambert which is a wine with powerful fruit intensity yet elegant structure and the long, classy finish of the very best Cahors.

I'm Shane. Macronesia is the outlet for my underwater macro videos. I'm a terrestrial ecologist by vocation and underwater videographer by compulsion, with a special penchant for nudibranchs, other sea slugs, and marine invertebrates of all types. This is a non-commercial site, I just want to share these moving images as widely as possible. Please share my videos with your friends, and "like" the Macronesia Facebook page to stay connected. Even better, submit your email address on the home page and never miss a new video.
